definition: Zhong Yao (151-230), minister of Cao Wei 曹魏[Cao2 Wei4] and noted calligrapher, said to have developed the regular script 楷書|楷书[kai3 shu1]
clock/o'clock/time as measured in hours and minutes/bell/CL:架[jia4],座[zuo4]
handleless cup/goblet/to concentrate/variant of 鐘|钟[zhong1]
surname Zhong
folk-song/forced labor
cause/means
interpretations of the trigrams

sentences.english: Emperor Xian commanded Zhong Yao to draft the edict confirming Cao Cao’s elevation to king of Wei.
sentences.chinese: 献帝即令钟繇草诏，册立曹操为魏王。

sentences.english: Wei Cao Pi had in the Chung Yeung chrysanthemum to giveZhong Yao, to wish him a long.
sentences.chinese: 魏时曹丕曾在重阳赠菊给钟繇，祝他长寿。

definition: Yan Zhenqing (709-785), a leading calligrapher of the Tang Dynasty
Xun Yu (163-212), brilliant strategist, advisor of Cao Cao in Three Kingdoms
Chu Suiliang (596-659), one of Four Great Calligraphers of early Tang 唐初四大家[Tang2 chu1 Si4 Da4 jia1]
Yu Shinan (558-638), politician of Sui and early Tang periods, poet and calligrapher, one of Four Great Calligraphers of early Tang 唐初四大家[Tang2 chu1 Si4 Da4 jia1]
folk-song/forced labor
cause/means
interpretations of the trigrams
Yuan Shao (153-202), general during late Han, subsequently warlord
Liu Biao (142-208), warlord
Cao Pi (187-226), second son of Cao Cao 曹操, king then emperor of Cao Wei 曹魏 from 220, ruled as Emperor Wen 魏文帝, also a noted calligrapher
Cheng Yu (141-220), advisor to General Cao Cao 曹操 during the Three Kingdoms era
Wang Xizhi (303-361), famous calligrapher of Eastern Jin, known as the sage of calligraphy 書聖|书圣
Cao Wei, the most powerful of the Three Kingdoms, established as a dynasty in 220 by Cao Pi 曹丕, son of Cao Cao, replaced by Jin dynasty in 265
Ouyang Xun (557-641), one of Four Great Calligraphers of early Tang 唐初四大家[Tang2 chu1 Si4 Da4 jia1]
Zhu Jun (-195), politician and general at the end of later Han
Sun Quan (reigned 222-252), southern warlord and king of state of Wu 吳|吴 in the Three Kingdoms period
Sima Yi (179-251), warlord under Cao Cao and subsequently founder of the Jin dynasty
Huangfu Song (-195), later Han general and warlord
